habitat_description:
Southwest:
The trumpeter swan occurs only in a few areas of the southwest region, primarily in isolated areas of Colorado and Nevada. In Nevada, this species is a resident in Elko County and probably a visitor as far south as Stillwater Marsh, Churchill County (Alcorn 1988). In Colorado, species occurs most often on large reservoirs (Andrews and Righter 1992).

Summer:
The trumpeter swan utilizes a wide variety of freshwater habitats, including marshes, ponds, lakes and occasionally rivers (Banko 1960, Hansen et al. 1971, Gale et al. 1987). This species avoids acidic, stagnant or eutrophic waters, or waters with abundant Nuphar luteum (Squires 1991, Matteson et al. 2007). Habitat requirements include space for taking off (approximately 100 meters); accessible forage (abundant and diverse aquatic plants and/or invertebrates); shallow, stable levels of clean, fresh water; emergent vegetation; structure for nest sites (muskrat houses, islands, etc); and low levels of human disturbance. The most productive breeding sites include waters with highly irregular shorelines (Hansen et al. 1971, Page 1976); water depths of less than 1.2 meters (Hansen et al. 1971, Maj 1983), and early ice melt, in combination with the requirements listed above (Lockman et al. 1987, Hansen et al. 1971, Holton 1982, Gale et al. 1987, Lockman et al. 1987, Shea 1979, Mitchell 1994).

Winter:
During the winter, the trumpeter swan can be found on freshwater springs, streams, rivers (Shea 1979, Lockman et al. 1987, Snyder 1991, Squires 1991), ponds (Banko 1960), lakes and reservoirs (Jordan and Caniff 1981, Gale et al. 1987, Babineau 2004, Varner 2008), as well as estuarine habitats (Farley 1980, LeMaster 1981, McKelvey 1981). They can be found foraging in croplands, pasture and estuaries. Winter habitat requirements include clean water free of ice (Snyder 1991, Squires 1991), open water at least 100 meters in length or width for taking off (15 meter width for flowing water), banks with little or no shrub cover, water depths of 0.6 – 1.3 meters for foraging, shallow water (less than 10 cm) or sand/gravel bars for loafing and roosting, and abundant, diverse vegetation, and little or no human disturbance (Mitchell 1994).
